Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41477 
March 2008 
 
 
 
Anticorruption Seminars, 2008–2009 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  OAGI  –  Integrity Division, Office of the Auditor General 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Public finance and expenditure management 
Theme  –  Governance 
Subtheme  –  Anticorruption  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Director  C. Wee, Integrity Division, OAG 
   
Team leader  A. Egloff, Senior Integrity Specialist, OAG 
Team members  C. G. Ortega, Senior Audit Officer, OAG 
  T. P. Jacob, Assistant Integrity Coordinator, OAG

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The anticorruption policy1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has three objectives: 
(i) to support competitive markets and efficient, effective, accountable, and transparent public 
administration as part of ADB’s broader work in good governance and capacity building; (ii) to 
support promising anticorruption efforts and improve the quality of dialogue on governance and 
corruption with developing member countries (DMCs); and (iii) to ensure that ADB projects and 
staff members adhere to the highest ethical standards. This technical assistance (TA) project 
focuses on the third objective.  
2.  Introducing  and  improving  frameworks  for  procurement,  implementation,  and  audit 
practices for ADB projects, and enhancing the capacity of DMC officials to detect, deter, and 
address potential fraud and corruption in ADB-financed projects, will make the DMCs better 
equipped to achieve the objectives of ADB projects. Because fraud and corruption usually 
entails concealment, a different set of skills is needed to prevent and detect these crimes. DMC 
officials and other stakeholders will be trained to recognize and detect these elements and to 
understand the psychology of motivation and rationalization behind fraud and corruption, as well 
as  to  detect  weaknesses  in  the  internal  controls  of  their  organizations.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the TA project is in Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB  affirms  that  corrupt  and  illicit  behavior  seriously  threatens  development.  The 
anticorruption policy is part of ADB’s broader effort to advance transparency, predictability, 
accountability, and participation under its governance policy2 and its second governance and 
anticorruption action plan. The Integrity Division, Office of the Auditor General (OAGI), is the 
focal point of contact for allegations of fraud and corruption in ADB-financed projects and 
among staff involved in these projects, and the sole office designated by the anticorruption 
policy to investigate such allegations. 
4.  OAGI coordinates with ADB’s regional departments and the Central Operations Services 
Office to ensure the timely detection and prevention of fraud and corruption in ADB operations. 
OAGI  has  audited  procurement  in  selected  ADB  projects  since  2003.  It  has  promoted 
compliance with the anticorruption policy by providing resource speakers for ADB-sponsored 
seminars  and  conducting  workshops  and  seminars  for  borrowers  and  executing  agencies. 
However, these efforts must be expanded to expose DMC officials and other stakeholders to 
indicators of fraud and corruption, outline measures to address such concerns, and emphasize 
borrowers’  obligations  to  perform  adequate  due  diligence  in  implementing  ADB-financed 
projects. 
5.  Through periodic seminars OAGI will be able to increase the awareness of fraud and 
corruption  among  borrowers,  executing  agencies,  supreme  audit  institutions,  and  other 
stakeholders  responsible  for  or  involved  in  project  administration,  procurement,  audit,  and 
anticorruption efforts in DMCs. Participants will be trained in, among other things, the best 
practices in proactive operational work, including organizing and managing operations in a 
manner that counters fraud and corruption. OAGI will assist and train operational staff and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The  objective  of  the  TA  is  to  reduce  the  risk  of  fraud  and  corruption  in  selected 
ADB-financed  projects  by  increasing  the  understanding  of  and  compliance  with  ADB’s 
anticorruption policy and raising the awareness of potential irregularities throughout the project 
organizations  implementing  these  projects,  including  representatives  of  executing  and 
implementing agencies, project management and implementation units, project management 
consultants,  members  of  steering  and  evaluation  committees,  beneficiaries,  and  other 
stakeholders, and thus help strengthen project administration. The TA beneficiaries will better 
understand ADB’s anticorruption policy and related procedures and be able to identify and 
address potential fraud and corruption in ADB-financed activities.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  In consultation with the regional departments OAGI will select six to nine new, large, or 
specifically vulnerable projects in DMCs in Central and West Asia, South Asia, and Southeast 
Asia,  and  conduct  anticorruption  training  for  officials,  consultants,  beneficiaries  and  other 
stakeholders involved in these projects. Other regions may be considered, subject to budget 
availability and project priority or sensitivity. 
8.  Local  seminars  consisting  of  up  to  three  1-day  training  sessions,  each  one  with  a 
maximum of 30 participants, will be held for selected projects. OAGI will conduct the seminars in 
coordination with local anticorruption commissions or supreme audit institutions in the second 
half of 2008 and in 2009. Responsible regional department project officers, in conjunction with 
governments,  will  nominate  participants.  The  list  of  nominees  will  be  submitted  to  the 
governments for endorsement. Additional nominations from the governments may be accepted, 
subject to confirmation by ADB. ADB’s resident missions and counterpart agencies in DMCs 
may  recommend  government  or  ministry  officials.  All  participants  must  have  a  working 
knowledge of English. 
9.  The seminars will deal with ADB’s anticorruption policy and ways to prevent and detect 
fraud and corruption in ADB-financed projects, such as procurement audit methods, and will 
allow participants to share experiences and discuss procurement and governance issues. The 
seminars may also form part of project implementation and administration seminars of the 
Central Operations Services Office if appropriate and targeting the same projects selected in 
coordination with the regional departments. 
10.  The seminars will consist of lectures and presentations by OAGI’s integrity specialists, 
local anticorruption authorities and supreme audit institutions, and other appropriate resource 
speakers, and will cover topics such as field experiences and lessons learned, including case 
studies on specific anticorruption issues.

3
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The cost estimates are based on a total of 15 days of training covering projects in six to 
nine DMCs in three regions, and ideally conducted in three batches of consecutive seminars to 
maximize  travel  costs.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $450,000  equivalent 
(Appendix 2). The TA will be financed with a grant from ADB’s TA funding program. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
12.  ADB, through OAGI, will be responsible for implementing the TA, including planning the 
seminar contents and preparing the presentation and training materials. OAGI will recruit one 
national  individual  consultant  for  a  total  of  12  person-months  to  make  the  administrative 
arrangements for the seminars. The consultant will be hired by ADB according to its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The consultant must be 
knowledgeable  about  ADB’s  setup,  policies,  procedures,  and  operations.  Outline  terms  of 
reference for the national consulting services are in Appendix 3. 
13.  The TA will begin in April 2008. The first batch of seminars will be held in the second half 
of 2008 and is intended to cover up to three projects in DMCs in Southeast Asia, subject to the 
priority of projects selected in coordination with the regional departments. The next batch of 
seminars will be held in 2009 and is planned to cover up to three projects in Central and West 
Asia during the first half of 2009, and in South Asia during the second half of 2009. The 
estimated completion date is December 2009. All materials and services will be purchased 
according  to  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
No-objection or concurrence letters will be obtained from participating DMCs. No TA activities 
will be carried out in a DMC until OAGI has received the DMC’s no-objection or concurrence 
letter.  
14.  The participants’ knowledge will be tested through questionnaires to be administered 
during the seminar. Their evaluation of the usefulness of the seminar and the logistic and 
administrative  arrangements,  at  the  end  of  each  seminar,  will  help  OAGI  to  continuously 
improve the seminars. Selected projects that also qualify for project procurement-related audits 
will be considered in OAGI’s annual planning cycle for projects that should undergo such audits.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis for 
Anticorruption Seminars, 2008–2009, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8   Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR NATIONAL CONSULTING SERVICES 
1.  A locally recruited consultant, in coordination with the Integrity Division, Office of the 
Auditor General (OAGI), will prepare and implement the regional anticorruption seminars in 
2008–2009 for representatives of borrowers, executing agencies, supreme audit institutions, 
and other stakeholders dealing with Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed projects. The 
consultant will also be primarily responsible for the administrative arrangements. The tasks will 
take a total of 12 person-months for the nine seminars. 
A.  Skills and Expertise 
2.  The consultant must be familiar with ADB’s setup, policies, and procedures, and should 
have experience in organizing regional training activities, seminars, conferences, or workshops 
involving various agencies and institutions in ADB’s developing member countries. 
B.  Scope of Work 
3.  The consultant will be recruited for an intermittent assignment of 240 days over a period 
of 2 years from March 2008 to March 2010 to arrange for participant invitation and coordination, 
organize logistics, provide support in the preparation and dissemination of seminar materials, 
and administer the seminars. 
C.  Tasks 
4.  The work of the consultant will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
(i)  Scheduling  and  coordinating  the  briefing  sessions  in  accordance  with  the 
modules and resource persons identified by OAGI. 
(ii)  In  consultation  with  the  senior  integrity  specialist  (and  the  seminar’s  overall 
coordinator)  and  the  regional  departments,  preparing  a  list  of  prospective 
participants  to  be  nominated,  including  arrangements  for  sending  invitations, 
following  up  nominations  and  invitations,  and  obtaining  a  confirmed  list  of 
participants.  Coordinating  and  making  arrangements  with  ADB  officials, 
government agencies, and participants to ensure that the process is smooth.  
(iii)  Coordinating  administrative  arrangements  for  the  participants  throughout  the 
program, including arranging travel, organizing the seminar venue, monitoring 
the budget, receiving incoming participants, arranging the lodging and payment 
of per diem of participants, posting the program activities on the ADB website 
and  intranet,  and  arranging  any  other  activities  necessary  for  the  program’s 
success. 
(iv)  Conducting an evaluation survey at the end of each seminar, and using the 
lessons learned to improve the next seminars. 
(v)  Monitoring and liquidating advances from the regional TA.
